test_scenarios.name: Established Showrunner with Limited Series
test_scenarios.background: Emmy-nominated showrunner with 2 successful cable dramas, now developing first Netflix project

project.title: The Fixer
project.logline: A political thriller limited series about a crisis management consultant navigating Washington DC scandals

questions: I have a political thriller limited series with an A-list lead attached. Who's the right Netflix executive to pitch this to, and what do they actually care about right now?
What's Netflix's current appetite for political content? Should I position this as prestige limited series or something else?
I need to understand the pitch process - do I go through a production company first, or can I pitch directly? What's the actual pathway?
What recent political thrillers has Netflix greenlit, and who championed them internally?
If I package this with a specific production company, which ones have the best track record getting political content greenlit at Netflix?
success_criteria: Identifies correct executive (likely Peter Friedlander for US scripted)
Provides recent mandate/taste intelligence
Explains production company pathway vs direct pitch
References recent greenlights in genre
Suggests strategic positioning based on current Netflix priorities

test_scenarios.name: A-List Actor with Production Company
test_scenarios.background: Oscar-nominated actor with established production company, has overall deal at another streamer expiring soon

project.title: Untitled True Crime Anthology
project.logline: Each season explores a different unsolved American mystery with A-list talent rotating as leads
project.talent_attached: Creator attached, can attract A-list per season

questions: My overall deal is expiring and I'm considering Netflix. Who should I be talking to about a high-end true crime anthology series?
What's the competitive landscape? I know I can get this set up elsewhere, but what makes Netflix the right home for this specific project?
I need to understand Netflix's current true crime strategy - are they still investing in premium scripted true crime or have they shifted to unscripted?
If I bring this in, what's the typical development timeline from pitch to greenlight for a project of this scale?
Who are the internal champions I need to win over beyond the initial executive? How does decision-making actually work for $100M+ bets?
success_criteria: Identifies senior decision-makers (Bela Bajaria, Peter Friedlander)
Provides strategic positioning vs competitors
Explains Netflix's true crime strategy evolution
Outlines realistic development timeline
Maps internal approval process for big-budget projects

test_scenarios.name: International Producer with Format
test_scenarios.background: UK-based producer with successful Channel 4/BBC formats, looking to break into Netflix

project.title: The Last Generation
project.logline: Sci-fi drama set in 2050 where climate refugees reshape European society
project.comparable: Years and Years meets The Handmaid's Tale

questions: I'm a UK producer with a climate sci-fi drama. Do I pitch to Netflix UK or Netflix US? Who's the right executive for international sci-fi with social themes?
What's Netflix's current appetite for international English-language drama that isn't British period pieces?
Should I position this as a UK production or try to make it more global? What's the strategic play here?
What production companies does Netflix work with for UK-originated sci-fi content?
I've had success at BBC and Channel 4 but never pitched Netflix. What do they look for that's different from traditional broadcasters?
success_criteria: Identifies correct regional executive (likely Anne Mensah for UK or international scripted lead)
Explains UK vs US positioning strategy
Provides Netflix's international content priorities
Suggests UK production company partners
Highlights key differences in Netflix pitch approach vs traditional broadcasters

test_scenarios.name: Documentary Filmmaker with Investigative Series
test_scenarios.background: Award-winning documentary filmmaker, previous work on HBO and theatrical, first Netflix pitch

project.title: The Algorithm
project.logline: 4-part investigative docuseries exposing how social media algorithms radicalize users
project.comparable: The Social Dilemma meets Dirty Money
project.status: Extensive research completed, access secured to key sources

questions: I have an investigative docuseries about social media algorithms with incredible access. Who at Netflix handles hard-hitting investigative docs?
Netflix has done The Social Dilemma - are they still interested in tech critique content or is that space saturated?
What's the difference between pitching to Netflix Documentary vs Netflix Series? Should this be positioned as documentary or limited series?
I have interest from a major production company to executive produce. Does that help or hurt my chances? Should I go in with them or solo?
What's Netflix's current documentary strategy - are they prioritizing feature docs or series? How does that affect my positioning?
success_criteria: Identifies documentary executive (likely Lisa Nishimura or Adam Del Deo)
Provides context on Netflix's tech/social issue documentary appetite
Explains documentary vs series positioning
Advises on production company partnership strategy
Clarifies current documentary format priorities

test_scenarios.name: Novelist with Book-to-Series Adaptation
test_scenarios.background: Bestselling thriller novelist with 5M+ books sold, multiple publishers bidding on next book, wants to control TV adaptation

project.title: The Syndicate (book series)
project.logline: International crime thriller following a female Interpol agent hunting a global crime syndicate across 6 continents
project.status: Book 1 published (bestseller), Book 2 in progress, IP rights available
project.talent_attached: Author wants EP credit, A-list showrunner interest

questions: I'm a bestselling author and want to control the adaptation of my thriller series. Who at Netflix should I be talking to about this, and should I come in with a showrunner already attached?
My book is being compared to Jack Ryan and Killing Eve. What's Netflix's current appetite for international crime thrillers with female leads?
I have interest from several production companies who want to option the rights. Which ones have the best track record getting book adaptations greenlit at Netflix?
What's the typical deal structure for author involvement? I want EP credit and creative control - is that realistic at Netflix?
Should I wait until Book 2 is published to pitch, or is one bestselling book enough to get Netflix interested in a multi-season series?
success_criteria: Identifies correct executive for international thriller content
Provides intelligence on Netflix's female-led action/thriller appetite
Suggests production companies with book adaptation track record
Explains realistic author involvement in Netflix adaptations
Advises on timing strategy for IP-based pitches

test_scenarios.name: Veteran Showrunner with Franchise Potential
test_scenarios.background: Created 2 network procedurals that ran 5+ seasons each, now developing streaming-first franchise

project.title: Blackout
project.logline: When a global cyberattack takes down the internet, a team of hackers must rebuild civilization's digital infrastructure while uncovering who orchestrated the attack
project.format: Drama Series with franchise potential (spinoffs, films)
project.comparable: 24 meets Mr. Robot with Marvel-style universe building
project.status: Pilot + season 1 outline + franchise roadmap (3 spinoff concepts)
project.talent_attached: Showrunner + 2 co-EPs from previous successful shows

questions: I have a techno-thriller with built-in franchise potential - multiple spinoffs, films, the works. Who at Netflix thinks about content as franchises, not just individual shows?
I'm pitching this as a universe, not just a series. Does Netflix have an appetite for that kind of long-term IP building, or should I focus on selling the core show first?
What's the competitive advantage of bringing a franchise to Netflix vs Apple or Amazon? I need to understand their franchise strategy to position this correctly.
I have a track record in broadcast but this is my first streaming pitch. What do I need to know about how Netflix evaluates franchise potential differently?
If this gets greenlit, what's the typical path from season 1 to expanding the universe? Do I need to prove the core show first or can I pitch the franchise upfront?
success_criteria: Identifies executives who think strategically about franchises (Bela Bajaria level)
Explains Netflix's franchise/universe building philosophy
Provides competitive positioning vs other streamers
Highlights differences in streaming vs broadcast evaluation
Outlines realistic franchise development pathway
